STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 28, 2022
Kevin Mitchell
Washtenaw County Youth Center
4125 Washtenaw Avenue
Ann Arbor, MI 48104
RE: License #: CE810254752
Washtenaw County Youth Center
4125 Washtenaw Avenue
Ann Arbor, MI 48104
Dear Mr. Mitchell:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
03/21/22. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Kari Muntean, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 395-0920
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
(e) One of ten new employee files reviewed had all three references, but one was
not dated. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 07/01/21, and CAP, signed
07/28/21. The facility must identify why the previous plan failed and how they
are going to ensure compliance.
(i) Six of 13 employee files reviewed were found to have central registry clearances
that were not completed timely. Two of the clearances were done prior to 30 days
before hire (33 and 34 days prior) and four were done late (one being done about
five months after hire, and the other three being one or two months late on the
annual clearances). REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 07/01/21, and CAP,
signed 07/28/21, and Renewal Report, 04/15/2020 and CAP, 04/24/20. The
facility must identify why the previous plan failed and how they are going to
ensure compliance.
(j) Three of three existing employee files reviewed had late (2) or missing (1) annual
performance evaluations.
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
4

more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
One of three existing employee files contained an annual tuberculosis screening that
was completed late.
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
One of one applicable youth files reviewed was found to have a medication
administration record that did not document dispensing of one medication on one
day. No reason was provided for the missing documentation
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(c) A brief description of the resident's preparation for
placement and general physical and emotional state at the time
of admission.
(i) Documentation that the grievance policy was provided as
required in R 400.4132.
(c) One of three current resident files was found to be missing documentation for
resident’s preparation for placement due to not having documentation of orientation
being provided to the youth. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 07/01/21, and
CAP, signed 07/28/21. The facility must identify why the previous plan failed
and how they are going to ensure compliance.
(i) One of three current resident files was found to be missing documentation for
having provided the youth the grievance policy.
R 400.4154 Shelter care and detention institutions; service plans.
(1) Within 30 calendar days after admission and every 15
calendar days thereafter, an institution shall complete a written
service plan. The service plan shall include all of the following:
(a) The reason for continued care.
5

(b) Evaluation of service needs.
(c) Ongoing service needs.
(d) How service needs will be met.
(e) Unmet service needs and the reasons those needs are
unmet.
One applicable youth file was found to have a late 30-day plan. REPEAT
VIOLATION, Interim Report, 07/01/21, and CAP, signed 07/28/21. The facility
must identify why the previous plan failed and how they are going to ensure
compliance.
6

R 400.4161 Seclusion rooms; policies and procedures.
An institution approved to use a seclusion room shall establish
and follow written policies and procedures specifying its use.
The policy shall include, at a minimum, all of the following
provisions:
(e) Staff shall observe the resident at intervals of 15 minutes
or less and shall record the observation in a seclusion room log.
Video surveillance shall not be the only means of observation.
Two of three seclusion records reviewed were found not to have included
documentation of eyes-on checks. The youth secluded were in mechanical restraints
at the time, so a staff was stationed at their door to monitor them until the
mechanical restraints could be removed. The staff did not document checks as they
were stationed by the door, however, interval checks still need to be documented.
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the services
provided while in residence, including medical and dental
services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan recommendations,
including medical and dental follow up that is needed, have
been reviewed with the resident and with the parent and with
the responsible case manager.
7

(b) One of eight closed resident files did not document a summary of the services
provided while in care. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 07/01/21, and CAP,
signed 07/28/21. The facility must identify why the previous plan failed and
how they are going to ensure compliance.
(c) One of eight closed resident files did not document the resident’s needs that
remain to be met. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 07/01/21, and CAP,
signed 07/28/21. The facility must identify why the previous plan failed and
how they are going to ensure compliance.
(d) Two of eight closed resident files did not document services that will be provided
by the facility after discharge. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 07/01/21, and
CAP, signed 07/28/21. The facility must identify why the previous plan failed
and how they are going to ensure compliance.
(e) Two of eight closed resident files did not document a statement that the
discharge plan recommendations have been reviewed with the resident, parent, and
responsible case manager. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 07/01/21, and
CAP, signed 07/28/21. The facility must identify why the previous plan failed
and how they are going to ensure compliance.
R 400.4506 Fire drills and telephone.
(1) There shall be quarterly emergency fire drills for each staff
shift. Two of the drills shall include evacuations, unless
approved by the department, in writing, as clinically
contraindicated. Where a facility has a 24-hour staff shift, the
emergency drills shall be conducted at different times of the day
and night. Written records shall be maintained for each drill
indicating the date and time of the drill and, where evacuation
was part of the drill, the approximate evacuation time.
The facility fire drill logs did not document fire drills on all shifts quarterly, as
required. The facility is further advised to ensure the required documentation is
included in the logs.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is a noncontracted program who does not take DHHS youth.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is a noncontracted program who does not take
DHHS youth.
8

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 113
The facility was advised to ensure intern and volunteer files are organized to account
for all the required information in the rule.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
I reminded the facility administrators to ensure they are following their policy on
vehicle maintenance.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care or corporal punishment
during this licensing period.
The facility has submitted no acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The facility has not had any special investigations in over two years. There is
presently a special investigation, 2022C0207022, where the facility has recently been
cited for noncompliance with R 159 (1)(2) as they did not follow their restraint policy.
The CAP for this investigation was just approved 04/18/22, therefore compliance will
be assessed during the next period.
Overall, the facility continues to make efforts to keep restraints and seclusions to a
minimum. They make efforts to comply with the licensing rules, however, staffing
shortages appear to have impacted some of the documentation compliance as noted
in the violation section. This will need careful attention from the administration in the
next period.
9

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
April 28, 2022
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 28, 2022
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
10
